Are you copying from your mounted root p: That's not a particularly good idea.  It'd be better to boot from an optical disc and do the copy then.
If not, the safest way to copy a partition is to do something like: mkdir /mnt/root; mount -o bind / /mnt/root; cp -av /mnt/root/* /mnt/dest/
And if possible, close down things that might write to the disk... otherwise you may end up with inconsistencies in those programs' data

OK, the important thing to understand is that when you install grub, you need to tell it two things; where to write the bootloader stage1 right now, and where to tell that stage1 to look for more files when it's actually booting

The second thing is the ''root'' command in the grub shell, so if your old disk is (hd0) and your new disk is (hd1) you'll probably want: root (hd0,0).  The first thing (where to write the bootloader stage1) is the ''setup'' command in the grub shell, and in the example I am giving you would say: setup (hd1)
